Table of Contents

Enum NotificationAction

Namespace
NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums
Assembly
NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll

Represents the different types of user interactions or resolutions applied to a notification generated by the RSS reader application (new articles, feed errors, sync events, etc.).

public enum NotificationAction

Fields

Archive = 4

User clicked a custom action button to archive the related article/feed item.

Behavior:

  • Applies archive status to the associated article.
  • Marks notification as handled.
Clicked = 1

The user clicked/tapped the main body of the notification.

Behavior:

  • Typically navigates to the related content (article, feed, settings page).
  • Often triggers secondary actions (e.g., mark article as read).
  • Marks notification as resolved.
Custom1 = 8

First reserved slot for a context-specific custom action button.

Meaning depends on notification type (e.g., "Mute this feed", "Unsubscribe", "Share", etc.).

Should be documented per notification category when used.

Custom2 = 9

Second reserved slot for a context-specific custom action button.

Meaning depends on notification type (e.g., "View all in feed", "Report issue", etc.).

Should be documented per notification category when used.

Dismissed = 2

The user explicitly dismissed or closed the notification (swipe away, close button, etc.).

Behavior:

  • Removes the notification from view and prevents automatic re-showing for this event.
  • No secondary actions are triggered.
MarkAsRead = 5

User clicked a custom action button to mark the related article as read.

Behavior:

  • Sets article status to Read (if applicable).
  • Resolves the notification.
None = 0

The notification has not been interacted with yet (still visible or pending in notification center).

Behavior:

  • Notification remains eligible for display/re-display.
  • Default initial state when a notification is first created.
OpenInBrowser = 7

User clicked a custom action button to open the article/feed in the system web browser.

Behavior:

  • Launches external browser with the content URL.
  • May or may not mark content as read (configurable).
  • Resolves the notification.
Snoozed = 3

The user chose to snooze/postpone the notification.

Behavior:

  • Hides the notification temporarily (duration configured by user or default).
  • Notification may reappear after snooze period expires.
  • Does not resolve the underlying event permanently.
Star = 6

User clicked a custom action button to star/favorite the related article.

Behavior:

  • Sets article status to Starred (or adds star flag).
  • Resolves the notification.

Remarks

This enumeration tracks how (or if) the user responded to a displayed notification. It is used to:

  • Update notification state in the UI and persistence layer
  • Collect analytics on user behavior with notifications
  • Prevent duplicate notifications for the same event
  • Trigger secondary actions (e.g., mark article as read when notification is clicked)
  • Support snooze/dismiss/archive workflows

Notification actions are typically recorded when the user interacts with a system notification (toast, banner, tray icon popup) or with in-app notification elements.

Business rules and behavioral implications:

  • None indicates the notification is still visible/unresolved — it may continue to appear in notification center or re-surface on app open.
  • Most actions (Clicked, Dismissed, etc.) are terminal: they mark the notification as handled and prevent further automatic re-display for the same underlying event.
  • Snoozed is temporary — the notification is hidden for a user-configured period (e.g., 1 hour, until tomorrow) and may reappear afterward.
  • Actions like MarkAsRead, Star, Archive often cascade to the related article/feed (e.g., clicking a "new article" notification may set Clicked and simultaneously mark the article as Read).
  • Custom1 and Custom2 are reserved for future or context-specific buttons defined per notification type (e.g., "Unsubscribe", "Mute feed", "Share", etc.). Their exact meaning depends on the notification payload.
  • Once an action other than None or Snoozed is recorded, the notification should no longer be re-presented automatically for the same trigger.
